comments.body: For windows, does /mnt/test* file/dir were created for ephemeral volumes?

it must have otherwise it'd have returned a status code != 0, I confirmed running the test again:

```
C:/ $ ls -la /mnt
total 8
drwxrwxr-x    1 Containe Containe         0 Apr 05 18:42 .
drwxrwxr-x    1 Containe Containe      4096 Apr 05 18:42 ..
drwxrwxr-x    1 Containe Containe      4096 Apr 05 18:41 test-0
C:/ $ ls /mnt/test*
C:/ $ echo $?
0
```

Logs:

```
Apr  5 18:39:36.519: INFO: ExecWithOptions {Command:[/bin/sh -c ls /mnt/test* && (touch /mnt/test-0/hello-world || true) && [ ! -f /mnt/test-0/hello-world ]] Namespace:ephemeral-400 PodName:inline-volume-tester-7jlb2 ContainerName:csi-volume-tester Stdin:<nil> CaptureStdout:true CaptureStderr:true PreserveWhitespace:false Quiet:false}
Apr  5 18:39:36.519: INFO: >>> kubeConfig: /usr/local/google/home/mauriciopoppe/.kube/config
```

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +157,161 @@				// attempt to create a dummy file and expect for it not to be created
				command = "ls /mnt/test* && (touch /mnt/test-0/hello-world || true) && [ ! -f /mnt/test-0/hello-world ]"
			}
			e2evolume.VerifyExecInPodSucceed(f, pod, command)
			return nil
